instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No liquid damage- green light no fan spin
threads.message:
Hi Guys, Got a odd one here.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no liquid by the looks of it. i mean its very very clean!
gets a green light, heres what ive done so far with no success.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.6V 
PP3v42           3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.4v

Heres where it gets interesting, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN_L</SIGNAL> Jumps up and down, hence so do 5V and 3v3
ive replaced the SMC with no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No liquid damage- green light no fan spin
threads.message: Acts the same with the SPI rom removed. This seems to be an fully S5 related failure. my guess is something on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No liquid damage- green light no fan spin
threads.message: when the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> coil is removed it stops jumping up and down. Gota be something that runs of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> :( This boards a pain. Checked all rails for shorts, nothing seemingly out of place with anything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No liquid damage- green light no fan spin
threads.message: Isolated the voltage jumping up and down as an issue on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> line, as ive already replaced the bios, looks like the PCH has failed. odd symptoms though!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No liquid damage- green light no fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No liquid damage- green light no fan spin
threads.message: It will jump when <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> will not come high. <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> is a common issue too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No liquid damage- green light no fan spin
threads.message: <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present. TPS 51125 has previously been replaced.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No liquid damage- green light no fan spin
threads.message: <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> cannot be present if <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN_L</SIGNAL> is jumping up and down.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No liquid damage- green light no fan spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 12510"]<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> cannot be present if <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN_L</SIGNAL> is jumping up and down.....[/QUOTE]

Sorry, i skimmed that a little bit, When the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> mosfet is removed <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN_L</SIGNAL> remains solid. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> remains solid too. Hence thinking its down to the SUS line and suspecting PCH.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No liquid damage- green light no fan spin
threads.message: PCH replaced, Same symptoms, With the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pull-up <RESISTOR>R7933</RESISTOR> removed the current stabilises out. Clock Gen changed and crystal changed, no change in symptoms. Its something in PCH support.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No liquid damage- green light no fan spin
threads.message: I have no idea, there was no need to do the PCH. Could be anything at this point.
